p: In other research to identify new HIV-1 inhibitors, Corona et al., obtained some new 4-amino-5-benzoyl- N-phenyl-2-(substituted-amino)-1 H-pyrrole-3-carbothioamide derivatives ( Table 2, Compound 11) and tested them against RNase H activity [ 37]. In the group of the synthesized compounds, some exhibited IC 50 values in the low micromolar range. The authors concluded that the 4-methylbenzoyl moiety in the 2-amino group led to compounds that showed IC 50 values ranging from 6 to 8 μM (Compound 11, A1– A6), except for 4-chlorophenylamino and 3,4-dichlorophenylamino derivatives. Since only the 4-phenylamino derivative A8 among the Compound 11, A7– A13 retained some RNase H inhibition properties (IC 50 of 19 μM), the replacement of the 4-methylbenzoyl group with a 4-methoxybenzoyl group caused a loss of activity. However, the presence of 4-chlorophenylamino group in the case of the 4-chlorobenzoylpyrrole series ( A14– A17) did not affect inhibition of RNase H. Finally, the replacement of the aroyl moiety with a small alkylamino group ( A18) or a pyridylamino moiety ( A20) was detrimental for the anti-RNase H activity in the pyrrole derivatives bearing an unsubstituted benzoyl moiety, while its replacement with a phenyl acetyl moiety ( A19) preserved the activity.
